question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my last knowledge update in October 2023, Donald Trump Jr. has not officially declared his candidacy for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and there are several prominent candidates already in the race, including former President Donald Trump and other established political figures. While Donald Trump Jr. has a strong public profile and a significant following due to his father's influence, the Republican nomination process is competitive and often unpredictable. The Republican National Convention will consider various factors, including polling data, delegate support, and broader party dynamics, which may not favor Donald Trump Jr. Additionally, the political landscape could change significantly leading up to the convention, with new candidates potentially entering the race. Given these factors, it seems unlikely that Donald Trump Jr. will emerge as the nominee.

question.title: Will Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Asa Hutchinson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently considered; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Asa Hutchinson is a relatively lesser-known figure in the Republican Party and has not gained significant traction in the race for the 2024 nomination compared to other more prominent candidates. As of my last update, figures like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, and Nikki Haley have been leading the polls and garnering more media attention and support. Hutchinson's campaign has struggled to resonate with a broad base of Republican voters, and he lacks the fundraising capabilities and recognition that are often crucial for securing a party nomination. Given the competitive landscape and the dynamics of primary elections, the probability that Asa Hutchinson will emerge as the Republican nominee appears to be quite low.

question.title: Will both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson be the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson are selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates or combinations will resolve as **No**. It is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The likelihood of both Donald Trump Jr. and Asa Hutchinson being the Republican nominees for the 2024 US Presidential Election is quite low. Donald Trump Jr. has not held an elected office and his candidacy is largely dependent on the influence of his father, former President Donald Trump. Asa Hutchinson, while a more traditional political figure with gubernatorial experience, has been less prominent in the national conversation and has not shown significant traction in the Republican primary landscape. As of now, there are several other potential candidates, including former President Trump himself, who have a stronger base of support and recognition. Given the competitive nature of party nominations, it's improbable that both of these individuals would emerge as the nominees. Thus, the probability of this question resolving as YES is very small.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors. First, Biden's current political standing and the context of the 2024 election cycle are important. As of now, Biden is the incumbent president, and incumbents typically seek re-election unless there are significant health issues, scandals, or political pressures. Additionally, Biden's approval ratings and the state of the Democratic Party will influence his decision. If he believes he has a strong chance of winning or if there is no viable alternative candidate, he is less likely to step down. However, if there are significant challenges within the party or if he feels his presidency is at risk, he might consider announcing that he will not run. Given the timeline, there is still considerable time for events to unfold, and Biden's decision-making may be influenced by upcoming primaries, public opinion, and party dynamics. However, unless there are clear signs indicating a withdrawal from the race, it seems more probable that he will remain in the race until closer to the election date. Considering these factors, I estimate a moderate probability that he will announce he will not accept the nomination.

question.title: Will Kamala's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday August 9th at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

Link: https://www.natesilver.net/p/nate-silver-2024-president-election-polls-model

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess whether Kamala Harris's odds of winning will increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model, we need to consider several factors. First, we should examine current polling data and trends leading up to August 9th. If Harris's support is rising due to recent events, endorsements, or shifts in voter sentiment, it's plausible that her Electoral College probability could surpass the 46.6% threshold. Furthermore, Nate Silver's model typically accounts for various data points, including state-level polling and demographic changes, which could influence the overall probability.

Given the political landscape leading up to the election, if there are no significant negative developments for Harris and if she maintains or increases her support in key states, it is reasonable to expect her odds might improve. However, if there are major opposing campaign efforts or shifts in voter sentiment against her, that could counteract any positive trends.

Overall, while there is uncertainty inherent in political forecasting, the likelihood of her odds increasing could be considered moderately favorable based on historical trends and the dynamics of the election cycle.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President, and (2) Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?
question.body:
(1) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

This resolves Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

(2) Will Kamala Harris's odds of winning increase over the next week according to Nate Silver's model?

This resolves YES if the Electoral College probability for Harris in Nate Silver's model is >46.6% on Friday, August 9th, at 8:40 PM. Resolves NO otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question involves two distinct events that both need to occur for the overall question to resolve YES. 1. Regarding Joe Biden announcing that he will not accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024: As of now, Biden has not indicated any intention to step down or not seek re-election. Historically, incumbents often run for re-election unless there are significant health concerns or political pressures. Given that Biden has a strong base within the Democratic Party and the upcoming election is crucial for maintaining party power, it seems unlikely that he would make such an announcement. Therefore, the probability of this event occurring is relatively low. 2. For Kamala Harris's odds of winning increasing according to Nate Silver's model: This is dependent on various political dynamics, including Biden's decision. If Biden were to announce that he would not run, it would likely boost Harris’s odds as she could be viewed as a leading candidate for the nomination. However, if Biden remains in the race, it could dampen her prospects. Given the uncertainty of Biden's announcement and the fluctuating nature of political odds, the probability of Harris's odds increasing is also uncertain but could be seen as moderately likely if Biden does not run. Combining both events, the chances of both happening are lower than if they were independent events due to the interdependence of Biden's decision potentially impacting Harris's odds. Therefore, the overall probability of both events occurring is low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question pertains to the potential removal of Donald Trump from the primary election ballot based on Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which disqualifies individuals who have engaged in insurrection against the United States from holding office. While there have been discussions and debates surrounding this issue, as of now, there is no definitive legal precedent that guarantees his removal from the ballot. The interpretation and enforcement of Section 3 vary by state, and any actions taken would likely be met with significant legal challenges and political pushback. Given that the resolution date is in mid-2024, it is also important to consider that the political landscape can change rapidly. However, as of now, it seems unlikely that there will be a widespread removal of Trump from primary ballots across multiple states by that date, especially considering his significant support among Republican voters and the potential for legal battles to delay or complicate any removal efforts. Therefore, I estimate that the probability of Trump's removal from the ballot under these circumstances is low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of now, Donald Trump remains a prominent figure in the Republican Party and has significant support among the party's base. His previous presidency and ongoing influence in Republican politics suggest he will likely be a leading candidate for the nomination. Additionally, no other candidate has emerged with a strong enough following or organization to surpass Trump's established base. While there could be potential challengers, Trump's ability to mobilize his supporters and his name recognition give him a substantial advantage. Given the timeline leading up to the Republican National Convention and the historical tendency for the party to rally around a leading candidate, the probability of him being the nominee is relatively high.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Donald Trump is removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and (b) Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

(a) As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, this part resolves negatively.

(b) Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention. All other candidates will resolve as "No". This part may consider new candidates added in the future.

The question will resolve as "No" if either of these conditions is not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the likelihood of both conditions (a) and (b) occurring, we need to consider the legal and political landscape surrounding Donald Trump as of now and leading up to the specified date of July 15, 2024. 

For condition (a), the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which pertains to disqualification from holding office due to engaging in insurrection or rebellion, would require a legal process that could lead to Trump's removal from the ballot in at least one state. Given Trump's significant political influence and the Republican support he commands, the likelihood of him being officially removed or blocked from the ballot seems low. While there may be ongoing legal challenges, the requirement for an official removal or block by the specified date adds an additional layer of complexity. The courts may not act swiftly enough, or the legal arguments may not be strong enough to warrant such action.

For condition (b), Trump remains a dominant figure within the Republican Party, and as of now, he is widely expected to be a strong contender for the Republican nomination. Unless significant political shifts occur, it seems probable that he will be nominated again. 

Considering both conditions, the probability of both occurring is low, primarily due to the uncertainty and challenges surrounding the legal aspect of condition (a). Therefore, while condition (b) is likely, condition (a) appears to be less so, leading to the conclusion that the overall probability of the question resolving as "Yes" is quite small.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:
Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th. 

Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Assessing the probability of Joe Biden dying before the specified date involves considering several factors, including his current health status, age, and historical context regarding public figures in similar positions. As of the last available information, Joe Biden, born on November 20, 1942, is in his early 80s. While age is a risk factor for health complications, there is no significant information suggesting an imminent health crisis that would lead to his death before the specified date. Additionally, public figures often have extensive medical care and monitoring, which can mitigate many risks associated with aging. Given these considerations, the probability of an official announcement of his death occurring before the deadline appears to be very low.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden remaining President through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors. As of now, Joe Biden is serving as President and has shown no public intent to resign. The next presidential election is set for November 2024, and while political dynamics can change, it is not typical for a sitting president to resign or die unexpectedly within a short timeframe unless there are significant health issues or political crises. Additionally, Biden has faced challenges during his presidency, but he has also demonstrated resilience and has a support base within the Democratic Party. The likelihood of resignation or death is statistically low for a sitting president, especially considering Biden's current health status and his active role in politics. Given these factors, while there is always some uncertainty in politics, the probabilities indicate that it is more likely than not that Biden will remain President through the end of July 2024.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday and remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (a) There is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, and (b) Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET). Resolves NO otherwise. Note: Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not impact the resolution as long as he remains President.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around two critical events: the official announcement of Joe Biden's death before July 26, 2024, and his continued status as President through the end of July 2024. As of now, Joe Biden is alive and serving as President, and there is no credible indication or forecast suggesting a high likelihood of his death in the near future. Additionally, the political and health context surrounding a sitting president is generally stable unless there are significant health issues or unforeseen events, which are not currently evident. Given the low probability of the first condition (his death) occurring, the second condition (remaining President through July 2024) becomes irrelevant since the first condition must be met for the question to resolve YES. Therefore, the overall probability of both conditions being satisfied is extremely low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: The question revolves around the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which disqualifies individuals from holding office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. The likelihood of Donald Trump being removed from a primary ballot under this provision depends on several factors, including ongoing legal interpretations, political dynamics, and the actions of state officials and courts leading up to the election. As of now, there are no definitive legal precedents that would guarantee Trump's removal based solely on the 14th Amendment, and it is likely that any efforts to do so would face significant legal challenges and political resistance. Furthermore, the political environment is highly polarized, and many Republican officials and voters support Trump, which may deter state governments from taking such actions. Given these considerations, while there is a possibility of challenges to Trump's candidacy, the consensus among legal experts and political analysts suggests that it is unlikely he will be officially removed or blocked from the ballot in any state by the specified date.

question.title: Will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?

This question will resolve as **Yes** if Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Ted Cruz is a prominent figure in the Republican Party and has previously run for president in 2016, where he garnered significant support. However, the political landscape for the 2024 election is highly competitive, with multiple strong candidates emerging, including former President Donald Trump and Governor Ron DeSantis. The dynamics of the Republican primaries can shift rapidly due to various factors such as endorsements, fundraising, and changing voter preferences. As of now, Cruz has not positioned himself as the front-runner, and the presence of other candidates with substantial backing makes it less likely that he will secure the nomination. Given these factors, while Cruz has a chance, it appears relatively low compared to the competition he faces.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from any U.S. state's primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, and will Ted Cruz be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if both of the following conditions are met:

1. As of July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

2. Ted Cruz is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This is determined solely by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, regardless of who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election. 

The question will resolve as "No" if either or both of these conditions are not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question involves two distinct conditions that must both be satisfied for the answer to resolve as "Yes." 

1. **Donald Trump's Status**: The application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment is a legal matter that would require significant political and judicial action to remove Trump from any state primary ballot. While there have been discussions and some legal challenges regarding this matter, the actual implementation of such removals is uncertain. As of now, there is no definitive legal precedent that suggests Trump will be removed from any ballot under these grounds by the specified date. Additionally, political dynamics and public sentiment may influence state decisions, making removal less likely.

2. **Ted Cruz as the Nominee**: Ted Cruz has a strong political background and could be a contender for the Republican nomination. However, the Republican primary landscape is highly competitive, and many factors, including Trump's popularity and other potential candidates, could influence the outcome. Given Trump's established base, it is plausible that he could secure the nomination despite challenges. If Trump is not blocked from the ballot, it may significantly diminish Cruz's chances of being the nominee.

Considering both factors, the likelihood of both conditions being met seems low. The legal challenges regarding Trump's eligibility under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment are complex and would require significant political will to enforce, while Cruz's nomination is uncertain due to the competitive nature of the primary process.

question.title: Kamala president by Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

The primary resolution source for this market will be official information from the US government, however a consensus of credible reporting will also be used.

Resolver

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the probability of Kamala Harris being designated as President or Acting President before the specified date, we need to consider several factors. Firstly, as of now, she is the Vice President, and there are no immediate indications or events that would necessitate her taking over the presidency. The current President, Joe Biden, is in office and has not shown signs of stepping down or being incapacitated. However, political dynamics can change rapidly, and unforeseen circumstances such as health issues, political crises, or other significant events could potentially lead to her assuming the presidency before the deadline. Historically, Vice Presidents have ascended to the presidency in cases of resignation, death, or removal from office, but these events are relatively rare. Given the current political stability and the lack of any imminent threats to President Biden's position, the likelihood of Kamala Harris being formally designated as President or Acting President before July 26, 2024, appears low. Thus, while it is not impossible, it seems unlikely based on the current context and political landscape.

question.title: Will Biden drop out before July 20?
question.body: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of the current date, July 8, 2024, Joe Biden is the incumbent President of the United States and has been actively campaigning for re-election. There are no significant indications or credible reports suggesting that he is considering dropping out of the race before the specified date of July 20, 2024. Additionally, incumbents typically have strong motivations to continue their campaigns, especially when they are seeking re-election. While political landscapes can change rapidly, the likelihood of Biden withdrawing from the race in such a short time frame appears low given the context of the current political environment and his established position. Therefore, I would estimate a low probability of him dropping out before the given date.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Kamala Harris becomes President or Acting President by July 26, 2024, and (b) Biden drops out of the race before July 20, 2024?
question.body:
(a) This condition will be met if Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. The primary resolution source for this will be official information from the US government, or a consensus of credible reporting.

(b) This condition will be met if Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20, 2024, midnight Eastern Time.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To evaluate the probability of both conditions occurring, we must consider the current political landscape and the timeline outlined in the question. 

Condition (a) requires Kamala Harris to become President or Acting President by July 26, 2024. This could happen if President Biden were to resign, be incapacitated, or if he were to be removed from office through impeachment or other means. While the possibility of a resignation or incapacity exists, it is relatively low given that Biden is currently in office and there have been no significant indications that he plans to resign.

Condition (b) entails Biden dropping out of the race before July 20, 2024. As of now, Biden is the incumbent President and is expected to run for re-election. While political dynamics can change rapidly, the likelihood of him voluntarily dropping out is also low unless there are significant political or personal pressures.

Given that both conditions are somewhat dependent on Biden's actions and health, and considering the current stability of his presidency, the likelihood of both events occurring before the specified deadlines is low. However, since both conditions are not entirely mutually exclusive and could be influenced by unforeseen events, I would estimate a moderate probability that they could happen together, but still leaning towards the unlikely side.

question.title: Will INC form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the INC has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections. All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Indian National Congress (INC) has historically been one of the major political parties in India, but its influence has waned in recent years, particularly in the 2014 and 2019 general elections, where it faced significant losses to the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP). The political landscape in India is highly dynamic, and several factors will influence the INC's prospects in the upcoming 2024 elections, including the party's ability to form alliances, the effectiveness of its campaign strategies, and the public's sentiment towards the incumbent government. As of now, the BJP remains a strong contender, and the INC would need to overcome substantial challenges to secure a majority or form a coalition government. Given the current political climate and trends, it seems unlikely that the INC will form the government after the next election. Therefore, I estimate a relatively low probability of the INC forming the government.

question.title: Will BJP form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024)

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has been a dominant political force in India, especially since 2014, when it first came to power under Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Several factors contribute to the likelihood of the BJP forming the government after the 2024 general elections. These include their strong organizational structure, significant support from a large voter base, and the party's ability to project a strong leadership image. Additionally, the BJP has a track record of winning elections in various states and has a vast network of grassroots support. However, it is essential to consider potential challenges, such as the possibility of a united opposition, regional parties gaining traction, and public sentiment regarding issues such as economic performance, social policies, and governance. The opposition parties, including the Indian National Congress and other regional parties, are likely to attempt to form coalitions to challenge the BJP's dominance, which could affect their chances. Overall, while there are challenges ahead, the BJP's historical performance, current popularity, and organizational strength suggest a favorable outlook for them to form the government after the 2024 elections. Therefore, I estimate a relatively high probability that the BJP will have a member sworn in as the next Prime Minister.

question.body:

Historically, Indian politics has been characterized by a multi-party system, and it is rare for two major parties to form a government together unless there is a coalition agreement. Given the current political landscape, which includes the rise of regional parties and the potential for alliances, it seems unlikely that both the INC and BJP will be able to form a government together. Additionally, recent trends in Indian politics indicate a growing fragmentation of votes and a shift towards smaller parties, making a coalition between these two parties less probable. Therefore, the likelihood of both parties having members sworn in as Prime Minister is low.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The context indicates that there is significant discontent among House Democrats regarding the plan to virtually nominate President Biden early. With Rep. Jared Huffman leading the charge, it suggests that there is organized opposition that could rally support from other Democrats. The fact that this is being characterized as a serious concern among party members implies that there is a likelihood of at least 20 lawmakers signing a public letter. Given the timeframe until the resolution date, there is ample opportunity for this opposition to organize and gather signatures. The current political climate, where party unity is often tested, supports the idea that dissenting voices will coalesce, especially if they feel their concerns are not being addressed. Therefore, I believe it is probable that at least 20 Democratic lawmakers will sign such a letter.

question.title: Will 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?
question.body:
Resolution source: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2024/us/elections/biden-drop-out-democrats.html

If at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, it shows 10 or more Dem Senators, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, it will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the likelihood of 10 or more Democratic Senators calling for President Biden to drop out before July 20, we must consider several factors. First, the political landscape leading up to the resolution date is crucial. As of mid-July 2024, Biden's approval ratings, party dynamics, and the overall sentiment among Democratic Senators will play significant roles. If Biden is perceived as vulnerable in the upcoming elections, it could lead to increased pressure from party members to consider alternatives. 

However, Democratic Senators typically exhibit a level of loyalty to their party's sitting president, especially if they believe he has a viable path to reelection. The likelihood of 10 or more Senators publicly calling for him to drop out would require a significant shift in party sentiment, which is relatively uncommon unless there is overwhelming evidence of a loss of confidence in his candidacy.

Given the current political climate, it seems unlikely that such a substantial number of Senators would take a public stand against Biden without strong justification, such as a major scandal or a drastic decline in his electoral prospects. Therefore, while it is not impossible, the probability of this event occurring is low.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early AND will 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out before July 20?
question.body:
This question resolves to YES if both of the following conditions are met:

1. A public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before the end of Sunday, July 21st. This includes multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures.

2. 10 or more Democratic Senators call for Biden to drop out at any point before midnight July 20 Central Time, as confirmed by the New York Times source.

If both conditions are met, the question resolves to YES. If either or both conditions are not met, the question resolves to NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the likelihood of the conditions being met, we need to consider the political landscape and the dynamics within the Democratic Party as of mid-July 2024. 1. **Public Letter Opposing Early Nomination**: The Democratic Party is generally unified, especially in the lead-up to a presidential election. However, with growing concerns about President Biden's age and performance, there may be factions within the party that are willing to express dissent. The requirement for at least 20 lawmakers to sign a public letter is significant but not insurmountable. Given the current political climate, it is plausible that a coalition of progressive and moderate Democrats could rally to express their discontent, particularly if there is a perceived urgency to challenge the nomination process. 2. **Senators Calling for Biden to Drop Out**: The second condition is more stringent, requiring 10 or more Democratic Senators to publicly call for Biden to withdraw from the race. This is a high bar, as Senators typically weigh their public statements carefully, especially regarding a sitting president from their party. While there may be individual Senators who harbor such sentiments, it is less likely that a substantial group would collectively take such a bold step unless there is overwhelming consensus or pressure from constituents, party leaders, or major events leading up to this deadline. Considering these factors, while there may be some dissent within the party, the combination of both conditions being met seems unlikely. The probability of both events occurring simultaneously is diminished by the cautious nature of Senators and the general tendency of party members to support their president during an election cycle.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The United States has a strong historical performance in the Olympics, particularly in winning Gold medals. Traditionally, the USA has consistently outperformed other nations in terms of total medal count, especially Gold medals. In recent Olympics, the USA has often secured a significantly higher number of Gold medals compared to Silver medals. Factors contributing to this include the depth of talent in various sports, a well-structured training and development system, and substantial investment in sports programs. While there are always variables that could affect performance, such as injuries, competition from other countries, and the performance of individual athletes, the overall trend suggests that it is likely the USA will win more Gold than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics. Given these considerations, I estimate a high probability that the question will resolve YES.

question.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.

The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

metadata.chain_of_thought: The United States has a strong history in the Olympics, consistently ranking at or near the top of the medal table in previous Games. In the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, which took place in 2021, the US topped the medal table with 39 golds, 41 silvers, and 33 bronzes. The US Olympic Team has a diverse range of sports where they excel, including athletics, swimming, and gymnastics, among others. Additionally, the US invests heavily in its Olympic programs, leading to a well-prepared and competitive team. While other countries, such as China and Russia, have also been strong competitors, the overall trend and historical performance suggest that the US is likely to maintain its position as a top contender. Factors such as athlete performance, injuries, and the emergence of new sports could influence the outcome, but the US's overall strength and depth in various sports give them a significant advantage. Considering all this, while there is always uncertainty in sports, the likelihood of the US topping the medal table again at the Paris 2024 Olympics seems high.

question.title: Will the USA win more Gold than Silver medals and also top the Olympic Medal Table at the Paris 2024 Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (a) The United States Olympic Team wins more Gold medals than Silver medals at the Paris 2024 Olympics. (b) The United States Olympic Team is the unique highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics, based on the medal table that orders by number of Gold Medals, then Silver, then Bronze. The question resolves ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It resolves negatively if either condition (a) or (b) is not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The United States has a strong track record in the Olympics, historically winning a significant number of both Gold and Silver medals. Analyzing past performances, the USA has often secured more Gold medals than Silver, especially in recent Olympic Games. The USA also typically ranks at or near the top of the medal table, often leading in Gold medals. Factors such as athlete preparation, funding, and participation in a wide range of sports contribute to this success. However, there are always uncertainties, such as the performance of other countries, potential injuries, and the impact of the Olympic environment. Given the historical trends and the USA's robust Olympic program, it is reasonable to estimate a high probability that they will win more Gold than Silver medals and top the medal table in Paris 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Republican nomination process is complex and influenced by various factors, including public opinion, primary elections, party dynamics, and the political landscape leading up to the 2024 election. As of now, Donald Trump Jr. has not formally declared his candidacy for the 2024 election, and Chris Christie has shown interest but has faced challenges within the party. Historically, the Republican Party tends to favor candidates with established political backgrounds, and there is a significant chance that other candidates, including those with more political experience or stronger party support, may emerge as contenders. Given these dynamics and the uncertainty surrounding the nomination process, the probability that both Trump Jr. and Christie will be the Republican nominees is low.
